SalesTag.title: SalesTag
SalesTag.description: Represents a predefined sales tag for generating sales messages.

id.description: Unique identifier for the SalesTag entity.

name.description: The name of the sales tag (e.g., 'Greeting', 'Objection').

description.description: A description of the sales tag's purpose.

type.description: Categorization of the type of sales tag. (e.g. 'greeting', 'group', 'objection')

id.description: Unique identifier for the GeneratedMessage entity.

niche.description: The specific niche the message is tailored for.

generationTimestamp.description: Timestamp indicating when the message was generated.

definition.description: Stores predefined sales tags. Accessible to admins, if needed. Consider using a /roles_admin/{uid} collection to define administrators.

params.name: salesTagId
params.description: Unique identifier for the sales tag.

definition.description: Stores generated sales messages for each user. Path-based ownership is enforced through the /users/{userId} path, ensuring that only the authenticated user can access their own messages.

params.name: generatedMessageId
params.description: Unique identifier for the generated message.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to store sales tags and generated messages, prioritizing authorization independence and scalability. Sales tags are stored in a top-level collection, `/salesTags`, accessible to admins (if needed, a `/roles_admin/{uid}` collection could be introduced). Generated messages are stored within each user's document under a subcollection `/users/{userId}/generatedMessages`. This ensures path-based ownership and authorization independence.

The `/users/{userId}/generatedMessages` structure enables straightforward security rules based on `request.auth.uid`. Each user can only access their own generated messages. There is no reliance on parent document data, supporting atomic operations. The structure supports QAPs, as list operations are scoped to a user's messages and filtering is done on data within the document (rules are not filters).

This design simplifies security rules, enhances debuggability, and promotes scalability.
